context_evidences: - He had been facing trial on federal charges he used the Massachusetts Institute of Technology’s computer networks to steal more than 4 million articles from JSTOR, an online archive and journal distribution service. Reference: https://www.reuters.com/article/uk-swartz-internet/hundreds-attend-nyc-memorial-for-internet-activist-aaron-swartz-idUKBRE90J01520130120 published on 2013-01-20 04:36:27

- At 14, Mr. Swartz helped create RSS, the nearly ubiquitous tool that allows users to subscribe to online information. He later became an Internet folk hero , pushing to make many Web files free and open to the public. But in July 2011, he was indicted on federal charges of gaining illegal access to JSTOR , a subscription-only service for distributing scientific and literary journals, and downloading 4.8 million articles and documents, nearly the entire library. Reference: https://www.nytimes.com/2013/01/13/technology/aaron-swartz-internet-activist-dies-at-26.html published on 2013-01-12 18:47:44

- Swartz’s partner said it all became too much for him to bear. “He was so scared and so frustrated and more than anything so weary I just don’t think he could take it another day,” Stinebrickner-Kauffman said, adding the pair had discussed getting married after the trial. Reference: https://www.reuters.com/article/uk-swartz-internet/hundreds-attend-nyc-memorial-for-internet-activist-aaron-swartz-idUKBRE90J01520130120 published on 2013-01-20 04:36:27

- Aaron Swartz, a wizardly programmer who as a teenager helped develop code that delivered ever-changing Web content to users and who later became a steadfast crusader to make that information freely available, was found dead on Friday in his New York apartment. Reference: https://www.nytimes.com/2013/01/13/technology/aaron-swartz-internet-activist-dies-at-26.html published on 2013-01-12 18:47:44
correction_response:
This tweet is partially misleading. While it's true that Aaron Swartz committed suicide, he was not sentenced to 35 years in prison. At the time of his death, charges were pending against him, carrying potential penalties of up to 35 years in prison and $1 million in fines. However, he was offered a deal to plead guilty and spend six months at a low-security facility. The charges were related to his alleged illegal access to JSTOR and downloading of a large number of articles. 
References:
https://www.nytimes.com/2013/01/13/technology/aaron-swartz-internet-activist-dies-at-26.html
https://www.reuters.com/article/uk-swartz-internet/hundreds-attend-nyc-memorial-for-internet-activist-aaron-swartz-idUKBRE90J01520130120
note_1_text: Swartz was never convicted or sentenced to prison. After declining a plea bargain in which he'd serve six months in jail, he committed suicide before trial.    https://www.forbes.com/sites/timothylee/2013/01/17/aaron-swartz-and-the-corrupt-practice-of-plea-bargaining/?sh=59c753147d1c
note_2_text: Aaron Swartz was never sentenced. Prosecutors indeed put pressure on Aaron that could have contributed to his mind-state when he died but they did not ask for 35 years. He was still in the pre-trial portion of his case when he tragically took his life.
